I don't understand why this is a problem. If your class implements three
interfaces, then you have three test cases for that class, each a
subclass of the corresponding abstract test for each interface. Run them
all. No law says you must have one test case per production class, and
in fact, you probably shouldn't!



It's a simple matter of keeping the test tree as understandable as the
source it is testing. If there are too many test classes testing a
single source class, it become difficult to look at a package for the
first time and understand what is going on. The link that Paolo sent on
an earlier post has a link showing the use of inner classes to organize
the abstract test cases. The benefit is that I can enter a package, look
for a single class WidgetTest.java and be able to track back all of the
tests associated with Widget.java.


>Also, only some objects implement the equals method. These
>I have a standard set of tests to ensure that null and a few other
>scenarios are handled correctly (as well as the hashcode / equals
>relationship). I would like to have these standard tests available for
>different objects without having to rewrite them all the time.

GSBase's EqualsTester for testing equals(). JUnit-addons also has
something, but I can't remember the name of it.



Thanks, I'll check it out.
